𝟖 𝐌𝐲𝐭𝐡𝐬 𝐁𝐮𝐬𝐭𝐞𝐝 𝐖𝐡𝐢𝐜𝐡 𝐄𝐯𝐞𝐫𝐲 𝐏𝐞𝐫𝐬𝐨𝐧 𝐖𝐡𝐨 𝐖𝐢𝐬𝐡𝐞𝐬 𝐭𝐨 𝐒𝐭𝐚𝐫𝐭 𝐚 𝐁𝐮𝐬𝐢𝐧𝐞𝐬𝐬 𝐌𝐮𝐬𝐭 𝐊𝐧𝐨𝐰: 📌𝟏.𝐘𝐨𝐮 𝐝𝐨𝐧'𝐭 𝐧𝐞𝐞𝐝 𝐚 𝐦𝐢𝐥𝐥𝐢𝐨𝐧 𝐮𝐬𝐞𝐫𝐬 𝐭𝐨𝐦𝐨𝐫𝐫𝐨𝐰. ➙You just need 100 users who can't live without your product. ➙Focus on creating deep value for a core user base. ➙Prioritize user retention and satisfaction over rapid acquisition. 📌𝟐.𝐘𝐨𝐮 𝐝𝐨 𝐧𝐨𝐭 𝐚𝐥𝐰𝐚𝐲𝐬 𝐧𝐞𝐞𝐝 𝐭𝐨 𝐫𝐞𝐢𝐧𝐯𝐞𝐧𝐭 𝐭𝐡𝐞 𝐰𝐡𝐞𝐞𝐥. ➙You can just work to make the wheel roll smoother. ➙Look for ways to improve existing solutions. ➙Innovation can come from refining and perfecting, not just creating from scratch. 📌𝟑.𝐘𝐨𝐮 𝐝𝐨 𝐧𝐨𝐭 𝐧𝐞𝐞𝐝 𝐭𝐨 𝐛𝐞 𝐢𝐧 𝐞𝐯𝐞𝐫𝐲 𝐦𝐚𝐫𝐤𝐞𝐭. ➙You just need to dominate one niche. ➙Become the go-to solution in a specific area. ➙Build expertise and reputation in one sector before expanding. 📌𝟒.𝐘𝐨𝐮 𝐝𝐨𝐧'𝐭 𝐧𝐞𝐞𝐝 𝐭𝐨 𝐫𝐚𝐢𝐬𝐞 𝐦𝐢𝐥𝐥𝐢𝐨𝐧𝐬 𝐢𝐧 𝐟𝐮𝐧𝐝𝐢𝐧𝐠. ➙You just need to build a sustainable business model. ➙Focus on revenue and profitability, not just growth metrics. ➙Aim for financial independence and control over your company's direction. 📌𝟓.𝐘𝐨𝐮 𝐝𝐨 𝐧𝐨𝐭 𝐧𝐞𝐞𝐝 𝐭𝐨 𝐰𝐨𝐫𝐤 𝟐𝟒/𝟕. ➙You need to work smart and build efficient systems. ➙Prioritize productivity and work-life balance. ➙Create processes that scale without burning out you or your team. 📌𝟔.𝐘𝐨𝐮 𝐝𝐨 𝐧𝐨𝐭 𝐧𝐞𝐞𝐝 𝐭𝐨 𝐜𝐡𝐚𝐧𝐠𝐞 𝐭𝐡𝐞 𝐰𝐨𝐫𝐥𝐝 𝐨𝐯𝐞𝐫𝐧𝐢𝐠𝐡𝐭. ➙You just need to change the world over 50 years. ➙Focus on sustainable growth and long-term impact. ➙Build a foundation that can evolve and scale over time. 📌𝟕.𝐘𝐨𝐮 𝐝𝐨 𝐧𝐨𝐭 𝐧𝐞𝐞𝐝 𝐭𝐨 𝐛𝐮𝐢𝐥𝐝 𝐚 𝐤𝐢𝐥𝐥𝐞𝐫 𝐩𝐫𝐨𝐝𝐮𝐜𝐭. ➙You need to build a winning product. ➙Prioritize user satisfaction over flashy features. ➙Aim for consistent value delivery rather than instant domination. 📌𝟖.𝐘𝐨𝐮 𝐝𝐨 𝐧𝐨𝐭 𝐧𝐞𝐞𝐝 𝐭𝐨 𝐬𝐨𝐥𝐯𝐞 𝐚𝐥𝐥 𝐭𝐡𝐞 𝐩𝐫𝐨𝐛𝐥𝐞𝐦𝐬 𝐨𝐟 𝐭𝐡𝐞 𝐰𝐨𝐫𝐥𝐝. ➙You just need to solve one tiny problem that your audience is actually going through. ➙Identify a specific, real pain point in your target market. ➙Excel at addressing this one issue before expanding. 🚀 Product-Driven vs. Business-Driven: What's Best for Your Company? 🌟 🔥 A Recent Challenge at Crobstacle: We faced a tough decision with a website project that wasn't up to our standards. Despite the potential financial loss, we chose to redo the entire site in just one week. Why? Because delivering exceptional value to our clients is paramount. 📊 Product-Driven Approach: - Quality First: Focus is on creating outstanding products that define the brand. - Long-Term Success: Historically, companies like Apple have succeeded by prioritizing product innovation, even when it meant short-term challenges. 📈 Business-Driven Approach: - Market Flexibility: Emphasizes adapting quickly to market demands and profit maximization. - Immediate Results: Often yields quicker financial gains but may sacrifice product quality. ⚠️ Learning from Giants: - Apple: Initially soared with groundbreaking products but faced criticism when it seemed to prioritize business over innovation. - Boeing: Struggled significantly after shifting focus from engineering excellence to cost-cutting and profitability, impacting its reputation and safety records. 👀 What We Learn: History tells if you are business-driven it's a perfect recipe for failure, so you have to strike the right balance. A product-driven ethos fosters innovation and customer loyalty, while a business-driven focus enhances adaptability and market responsiveness. What is the way you believe in tell me in the comments section 🙌🏻 #ProductDriven #BusinessDriven #Entrepreneurship #CustomerSatisfaction

Do you ever wish you had the power to see the future? 🔮 Having a scalable business gives you that power. Why? Because when your business is scalable, it has the flexibility and adaptability to respond to future possibilities that you can't see today, but you very much expect to happen. Case and point, Liz Cullen Whitehead and her "follow up like a machine" subscription service, TouchPoint. ------- Two years ago, Liz came to me with a bold idea. After seeing her clients struggle to consistently follow up with their prospects, she thought "I can coach people to do it, but to make it even easier – why not build a follow up machine?" And so we did. TouchPoint delivers timely and relevant updates to business owners about their specific prospects so that they have an easy reason to reach out at the exact right time. I helped Liz vet the business case, formulate the subscription model, and develop the technology that powers it. Pretty cool, huh? But here's what's even cooler. Two years later, Liz called me up with a brand new idea for how TouchPoint could serve an entirely new audience. "Can we do it?" she asked. "Absolutely," I responded without hesitation. That creative confidence was possible because we didn't build TouchPoint to only fit the version that Liz had originally dreamed up. Instead, we created it with scalability in mind, expecting things to iterate and change over time. That's exactly what happened, and now Liz is well positioned to introduce her offering to a brand new market with hardly any changes to the technology needed. That's the power of scalability, and that's why I approach every project I take with scalability in mind. ------- But I want to know from you, how do you factor in scalability when you implement new ideas? Have you ever wanted to introduce an offering to a new market? Did it go smoothly, or did it require an overhaul to the way you do things? Let me know in the comments below 👇 #scalability #adaptibility #newmarkets #entrepreneurship

Mastering the art of 'tiny gains' These are small, continuous improvements that keep you (and your business) ahead of the curve. They don't require some big budget or large team, but they can have a massive impact. Here are 3 ways you can start implementing them today: 1. Customer Feedback Loop: Regularly ask your customers for feedback and act on it. That loop keeps your content and products relevant and fresh. Set up post-purchase surveys to automate data that will be helpful. 2. Daily Learning Habit: Dedicate at least 30 minutes a day to learning something new related to your industry. If you do this, you'll stay ahead of trends and spot ideas faster than your competition. Use custom newsletters like MorningBrew to have relevant news delivered every morning. 3. Small Scale Experiments: Try new marketing strategies or product features on a small scale before you fully commit. You'll minimize risk while maximizing innovation. Ship, analyze, iterate, repeat. These may not seem big at first, but these tiny gains, done well over a long period of time, make a significant difference. #businessboost #entrepreneurship #businesshacks

🛍️ Exploring the Dynamics of Subscription-Based Models in Retail and Service 🛍️ Hey LinkedIn fam! 👋 It's Chris, your go-to small business coach and fellow entrepreneur. Today, let's dive into the fascinating world of subscription-based models in the retail and service sectors. 🚀 In an ever-evolving market, businesses are rethinking their strategies, and subscription models are stealing the spotlight. Why? Well, here are a few insights to ponder: 1️⃣ **Customer Loyalty Reinvented:** Subscriptions offer a unique way to build lasting relationships with customers. It's not just a transaction; it's an ongoing commitment that keeps clients coming back for more. The value extends beyond the initial purchase. 2️⃣ **Predictable Revenue Streams:** For businesses, predicting revenue is like navigating through uncharted waters. Subscription models bring a sense of stability. Monthly recurring revenue? Yes, please! It allows for better financial planning and strategic decision-making. 3️⃣ **Personalization Matters:** In the retail and service game, personalization is the name of the game. Subscription models enable businesses to tailor experiences, products, and services to individual preferences, creating a more intimate connection with customers. 4️⃣ **Adaptation to Changing Consumer Habits:** The way consumers shop and engage with services is evolving. Subscription models align with the modern customer's desire for convenience, customization, and a seamless experience. 🚀 How Do You Know When You've Achieved #ProductMarketFit? 🚀 In today's fast-paced business world, achieving Product-Market Fit is often seen as the holy grail before scaling your company. But what does it really mean, and how can you get there? 🔍 Product-Market Fit is the stage where your product resonates with users, both buyers and users, allowing your business to flourish and become profitable. In simple terms, it's when you're selling something people can't resist buying. 🎯 So, how can you be sure you've reached this pivotal point? At the early stages, qualitative metrics hold more weight than quantitative ones. It's not just about growing your customer base; it's about retaining them and making them your brand's enthusiasts. 🧐 One of the first indicators of success is people's willingness to pay for your product. It's not enough to attract visitors; they must open their wallets. And qualitative feedback is key – interviews, surveys, or direct communication. 📈 Signs of Product-Market Fit include shorter sales cycles, low churn rates, high conversion rates, and optimal user #retention. While it's not always easy to measure, a great suggestion from Sean Ellis is to ask your users how disappointed they would be if they couldn't use your product anymore. If over 40% would be "very disappointed," you're likely there. 🚀 Remember, in the world of SaaS, this process can be gradual. Explosive growth isn't always the proof of Product-Market Fit. Some successful entrepreneurs took time to build a solid business, focusing on acquiring new customers, high retention, and positive feedback. 📖 Ready to dive deeper into achieving Product-Market Fit? One of the biggest mindset shifts I've made is viewing dissatisfied customers as a gift. It may sound unconventional, when things are running smoothly, it's easy to get comfortable into a false sense of having it all figured out and then relax. But if you have vocal, dissatisfied customers, When a customer expresses their dissatisfaction, it's an opportunity to listen, learn, and adapt. That provides the spark to keep iterating and innovating relentlessly. Think about it: Instead of brushing off complaints, ask yourself "What persistent frustration are they voicing that we've missed?" Instead of defensiveness, get curious about "What unmet need could we be solving in a radically better way?" Those critical voices push you to keep raising the bar, rather than resting on what you have. Staying obsessed with dissatisfied customers does three things: → It keeps you hungrier than your competitors who may grow complacent with success → It forces you to see your products/services through a beginner's mind → It helps you get ahead of trends and continuously elevate your offerings As Jeff Bezos puts forward this core idea here, "Focus obsessively on the customer, not the competition." If you're always striving to delight those who aren't satisfied, you'll never stop inventing on behalf of the people who matter most. What's one way you've turned dissatisfied customers into a driving force for innovation? #CustomerSatisfaction #Entrepreneurship #FounderPerspective
